review.title: Finetuning Randomized Heuristic Search For 2D Path Planning: Finding The Best Input Parameters For R* Algorithm Through Series Of Experiments
review.abstract: Path planning is typically considered in Artificial Intelligence as a graph searching problem and R* is state-of-the-art algorithm tailored to solve it. The algorithm decomposes given path finding task into the series of subtasks each of which can be easily (in computational sense) solved by well-known methods (such as A*). Parameterized random choice is used to perform the decomposition and as a result R* performance largely depends on the choice of its input parameters. In our work we formulate a range of assumptions concerning possible upper and lower bounds of R* parameters, their interdependency and their influence on R* performance. Then we evaluate these assumptions by running a large number of experiments. As a result we formulate a set of heuristic rules which can be used to initialize the values of R* parameters in a way that leads to algorithm's best performance.
histories: 8 pages, 2 figures, 18 references. As accepted to the 16th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence:Methodology, Systems, Applications (AIMSA 2014), Varna, Bulgaria, September 11-13, 2014
review.COMMENTS: 8 pages, 2 figures, 18 references. As accepted to the 16th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence:Methodology, Systems, Applications (AIMSA 2014), Varna, Bulgaria, September 11-13, 2014

metadata.title: Finetuning Randomized Heuristic Search For 2D Path Planning: Finding The Best Input Parameters For R* Algorithm Through Series Of Experiments

sections.text: The final publication is available at Springer at http: / / dx.doi.org / 10.1007 / 978-3319-10554-3 _ 29Keywords: Route Planning, Grid, 2D, A *, R *, heuristic search

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, the fact is that most of them are able to move to a different world in which they are able than in a world in which they are able to live and live.

sections.heading: 2 R* algorithm for grid path planning
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Path planning problem
sections.text: Consider an 8-linked grid, which is a finite set of cells A = (a, b, c, WA, WA), which can be represented as a matrix AMxN = {aij}, where: i, j - are cell position indices (also referred to as i (a), j (a))) and WA, N - are grid dimensions. Each cell is either traversable or non-traversable and it is allowed to move from a traversable cell to one of its traversable neighborhoods. A metric function dist (also known to the AI community as diagonal heuristics) is useful for measuring the distance between any two cells: dist (aij, akl) = cd · min.

sections.heading: 3 Experimental analysis
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Testbed
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: To examine the influence of R* input parameters on the algorithm’s performance and
sections.text: values of real cities were used as percentage sources on these cells. WA: - Randomly generated grids with rectangular obstacles of different sizes (70 grids * 25 different parameters * 25 different parameters configurations = 1750 experiments); - Randomly generated grids with tetris-shaped obstacles of different sizes (70 grids * 25 different parameter configurations = 1750 experiments); - Grids containing models of urban landscapes (70 grids * 25 different parameter configurations = 1750 experiments); while the generation of grids containing rectangular and tetris-shaped cells, the latter were added one by one at randomly selected locations until the total number of non-traverable cells is equal or easily exceeds predefined thresholds, e.g. 30%. When adding each obstacle, its size and orientation was determined within predefined thresholds; grids cityscapes were semi-automatically generated and the cities were used as the sources.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: R * is a state-of-the-art randomized heuristic search algorithm and a powerful tool for solving 2D path planning tasks at low computing costs. However, in order to benefit from the use of R * in practice, 3 parameters of the algorithm must be "correctly" initialized asretically and experimentally.) The presented rules are easily applicable to any path planning task in any network world as they require no additional knowledge other than the position of start and target cells.

In our implementation of R* we use midpoint circle algorithm [18] to generate successors – see fig.
